name: Nightly news and laughs
description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

key_work.title: TV miniatures
key_work.credit_line:
Designed by Graham McGuffie
Emily Boutard and Megafun
key_work.brief_description: These six miniature dioramas reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.

constellations_primary.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_primary.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

start.title: Hey Hey It's Saturday
start.creator_credit: Somers Carroll Productions and United Media
start.brief_description: Hey Hey It’s Saturday was a long-running variety television program on Australian television. It initially ran for 27 years, from 1971 to 1999. Its host throughout its entire run was Daryl Somers.

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

end.title: Figurines (Collectibles)
end.brief_description: Long after the credits roll on a film or television series, the characters might live on in our hearts and minds. They can also live on physically, in our homes and offices, as collectibles that pay homage to our passions. That can be in the form of Felix The Cat, a black and white cartoon from the silent film era, or One-Punch Man, a viral hero from a cult Japanese web comic turned anime. Figurines sometimes become more famous that the original screen character, like Margot Robbie’s Harley Quinn from Suicide Squad (2016) who became a pop cultural icon thanks to her own spin-off film Birds of Prey.

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

links.description: Plucka Duck was one of the most popular characters in Hey Hey It’s Saturday, probably because he gave away prizes. In Edie Kurzer’s display in the Fed Sq foyer, you can catch a peek of him among the other iconic characters.

start.title: TV miniatures
start.credit_line:
Designed by Graham McGuffie
Emily Boutard and Megafun
start.brief_description: These six miniature dioramas reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.

constellations_primary.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_primary.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

end.title: Deconstructed TV
end.brief_description: It’s hard to imagine, but television wasn’t always a 24/7/365 affair. TV stations used to stop broadcasting late at night when they ran out of programming. When off the air, they would commonly display a test pattern until the broadcast schedule resumed in the morning. Now television can be consumed free-to-air or whenever you want it thanks to on-demand and streaming services. This deconstructed TV was a National brand model, the kind of appliance mass produced in the 1970s. Today families are less likely to gather around a single TV set, instead favouring their own fractured shards of screen content

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

links.description: While the TV miniatures represent the spaces and places that Australians watched TV throughout history, the deconstructed TV in Edie Kurzer’s display in the Fed Square foyer symbolises the fractured nature of TV watching today.

start.title: Four Corners
start.brief_description: Four Corners is Australia’s longest-running investigative journalism/current affairs television program. It addresses a single issue in depth each week, showing either a locally produced program or a relevant documentary from overseas.

constellations_other.name: 1960s television
constellations_other.description: After its debut in the fifties, Australians rapidly became enthusiastic television viewers in the sixties as American imports started to be mixed with notable local productions.

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

end.title: A Current Affair
end.brief_description: A Current Affair is an Australian current affairs program airing weeknights on the Nine Network. The program is currently presented by Tracy Grimshaw.

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

links.description: Ten years after Four Corners premiered, nightly stalwart A Current Affair debuted with Mike Willesee as host and it also featured Paul Hogan with comedic social commentary. Though now considered a ‘tabloid’ show, rather than hard-hitting journalism, it remains popular.

start.title: A Current Affair
start.brief_description: A Current Affair is an Australian current affairs program airing weeknights on the Nine Network. The program is currently presented by Tracy Grimshaw.

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

end.title: Full Frontal
end.brief_description: Full Frontal was an Australian sketch comedy series which debuted in 1993. The show first aired on the Seven Network on 13 May 1993, and finished on 18 September 1997.

constellations_other.name: Eric Bana
constellations_other.description: There must be something that draws Australian creatives like Eric Bana to darker material as they shoot to stardom overseas. Australia's penal colony past perhaps?

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

constellations_other.name: Australian TV in the 1990s
constellations_other.description: In the 1990s, Australians and Australian culture was changing: so too were the representations of it on television.

links.description: News and comedy have always been part of Australian TV, often enjoying a complimentary relationship. We’re not sure how much ACA host Ray Martin felt when Eric Bana launched his career spoofing the news presenter on Full Frontal, in character as bogan Poida.

end.title: The 7.30 Report
end.brief_description: The 7.30 Report was an Australian nightly television current affairs program, that was shown on ABC1 and ABC News 24 at 7.30pm, Mondays–Thursdays.

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

links.description: One of Micallf’s most famous characters on Full Frontal was Nobby Doldrums, a huge fan of 7.30 Report presenter Kerry O’Brien, who insinuates himself to be on the program by agreeing to be interviewed about anything.

end.title: Hey Hey It's Saturday
end.creator_credit: Somers Carroll Productions and United Media
end.brief_description: Hey Hey It’s Saturday was a long-running variety television program on Australian television. It initially ran for 27 years, from 1971 to 1999. Its host throughout its entire run was Daryl Somers.

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

links.description: Debuting the same year as A Current Affair was another long-running staple of Australian screens, Hey Hey It’s Saturday. Based on the English variety show of the same name, it kept families entertained with comedy skits and iconic characters.

constellations_other.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_other.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

links.description: News and variety TV shows have been a staple of the Australian small screen since its arrival in the 1950s. The longest-running Australian news program is Four Corners, which has been running since 1961 and features award-winning investigations and documentaries.
